awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Dynamic Mechanisms without Transfers
awd_abstract_narration:
This project studies how to best allocate resources over time when money isn't available as a means of eliciting the agents' private information - an essential ingredient in the determination of the efficient allocation. Property rights to the allocation must dynamically respond to claims by the agents regarding their needs, punishing greedy agents and rewarding frugal ones, while attempting to preserve efficiency. Potential applications range from how to allocate hospital beds; how a nurse should divide up her time; how an agency should pick among competing projects, etc. The goal is to derive transparent and robust yet effective decision rules.

We allow the agent's private information to be serially correlated over time (but independent across agents), and consider both the cases in which agents desire only one unit (e.g., a medical procedure), and in which their payoff is additive in the number of units they get. Values are private. The principal is committed to the mechanism, and the resource supply is exogenous. In some simple settings, a two-part tariff using a virtual budget implements the optimum. For more complicated settings, the project will rank standard procedures (e.g., auctions with virtual budgets) and compare their performance to the best mechanism.

por.por_cntn:
The project has investigated how to allocate scarce resources in the absence of transfers. Economic transactions in which monetary payments do not take place, either for legal, practical or ethical reasons abound: product reviewers cannot be paid for reviews (they can be too easily made up),  patients that request expensive analgesic drugs, researchers competing for limited computing resources, etc. In all these cases, the agent has private information regarding the acuteness of his need, yet independent of this private information, he would like to get the resource allocated to him. This makes the problem of the designer difficult, as he cannot elicit this information via variable transfers. The instrument that we consider is his ability to use time as a substitute, namely, granting resources dynamically as a function of the requests in a way to elicit truth-telling to the largest extent possible. The designer can do so directly, in the case in which he owns or manages the scarce resource himself, or via a rating that allows those who manage the resource to base their decisions on the history of reports or actions of the agent. In the main project (joint with Y. Guo), the needs are correlated over time: an agent with a higher need today is more likely to have a higher need tomorrow. We solve for the optimal mechanism that the designer should use, which takes the form of a token mechanism with transitions (as a function of the reports) that are straightforward to implement. In ongoing work, we are extending this mechanism to the case in which there are several agents directly competing for the resource (so that all reports matter). In published work (joint with N. Lambert), we solve for the optimal rating system that the market can use to base its allocation decisions.
